_prev_prog_3.Description:
Royal Palm Beach Wastewater Treatment Facility Prevention Program Description

The Royal Palm Beach Wastewater Treatment Facility's (Facility) prevention program required under 112(r) was developed and put into place prior to the June 21, 1999 Risk Management Plan deadline. The Facility has used a proactive process of identification, evaluation, and mitigation to prevent and or control chemical releases.

Improvements for the Facility are currently under design. As part of these improvements, the Facility will be switching from chlorine gas as a disinfectant to sodium hyperchlorite. Construction is scheduled for the latter part of 1999.

In the interim, the Facility's program involved a systematic approach designed to critically evaluate all components of the chlorination processes: design, technology, operation, maintenance procedures, emergency plans, training programs, and other pertinent process elements. 

After evaluating the operations, the Facility took proactive steps to ensure that inventories of chlorine at each site were managed efficiently and safety and training programs were updated. 

The Facility has also reinforced its plans to manage public safety in the event of a release. Several meetings have taken place involving the Water Resources Dept., City Engineer, Fire Department, Safety Officer, Police Dept., Dispatchers, and Parks and Recreation.

The Village of Royal Palm Beach takes seriously its responsibility to operate its water plants in a safe manner and has therefore, taken the above mentioned proactive measures.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
In response to the chemical Accident Prevention Provisions (40 Code of Federal Regulations Part 68), the Village of Royal Palm Beach Utilities Department has prepared the following risk management plan. The Village owns and operates both water and wastewater treatment facilities.  The wastewater treatment facility is located on approximately 160 acres at 980 Crestwood Boulevard North.  The facility is classified by the Florida Department of Environmental Protection (FDEP) as a Type I WWTF.  The facility is also a secondary treatment facility with a current permitted capacity of 2.2 mgd. The 40 CFR 68.130 regulated substances identified at the wastewater facility include chlorine (disinfectant) and diesel fuel. With the exception of chlorine, the on-site quantities for these chemical substances are less than the threshold quantity identified under 40 CFR 68.130.

The Village of Royal Palm Beach Utilities Department recognizes the risks and dangers of working with toxic chemicals common to the wastewater treatment industry.  As such, the Village places the health and safety of its employees and the surrounding public, and the protection of the environment as a top priority.  In complying with this policy, the wastewater treatment facility will be switching from chlorine as a disinfectant to sodium hypochlorite solution as part of its plant improvement.  Construction on the improvements of the wastewater facility is scheduled for the latter part of 1999.  In the interim, the Village adheres to a strict policy of administering safety management procedures.  It also provides continuous training of employees that handle, or work in close proximity to the toxic chemicals located at its facilities.  The procedures and training address both the prevention of accidental chemical releases and the protocol for responding to potential emergency situations.

The Utilities Department has instituted procedures for accidental release prevention.  The topics addressed include handlin

g of chlorine cylinders during physical transfer at the site, location and atmosphere conducive to proper storage of chlorine cylinders, placement of chlorine cylinders into service, and removal of chlorine cylinders from service.  The operators at the facility, most of whom are Florida State Certified Operators, have years of experience safely handling chlorine.  They receive updated training regarding operations and safety on a regular basis. To prepare for an emergency at the wastewater treatment facility, the operators have been trained in the following: Respiratory Protection, Emergency Action and Fire Protection.  The facility is also equipped with emergency leak kits and personal protective equipment to support addressing emergency releases. The operators are also trained to repair equipment, valve and piping leaks, and container leaks that may occur while in transit, storage, or in service.

The Utilities Department estimates, in accordance with the assumptions established under 40 CFR 68, that a 1.3 mile radius extending from the facility may potentially be impacted with the release of 2000 pounds of chlorine within a 10 minute period (worst case scenario).  In a more realistic estimate for the release of approximately 740 pounds of chlorine over a 20 minute period (alternative release scenario), it is estimated that 0.1-mile radius extending from the facility may potentially be impacted. The Utilities Department has instituted an emergency response program with the Palm Beach County Fire Department (PBCFD) in the event of either scenario.  The program has detailed procedures addressing communication with the PBCFD, and protocol for evacuating potentially impacted areas.

There have been no accidental releases of chlorine at the wastewater treatment facility over the past five years that have resulted in deaths, injuries, evacuation, sheltering in place, or damage to property or the environment.
